reviewText:
I have been looking forward to this film for a couple of years now since I first heard about its upcoming realease on animated-movies.com and may I say was highly disappointed by the trailer. When I saw the first snip of animation I immediately thought that it was live action but with some odd touch. As Mr. Zemmicks has attempted to create an almost believable world on the computer I wonder "why not just create it and film it?". It would look a lot better and would be way cheaper to produce.
Aside from the animation there was very little else to comment on inside the trailer. There were very few lines spoken and very few scenes shown. Since this was a full-leignth trailer I would definitely considder this to be a hint towards what to expect of the quality of the film. With Mr. Zemmicks amazing directing abilities I would have expected a lot of expansion on the children's book's themes and storylines, but it doesn't appear to be so.
Although this might be a fun holiday movie to go see simply for the sake of seeing a Christmas film, I would definitely not recommend it for viewing outside of that purpose.
If one were considdering going to see this movie simply to see some of the ground-breaking realistic animation I would say you probably won't be disappointed. It's not perfect, but it's miles beyond even what PIXAR has thus accomplished. But aside from the animation, there doesn't appear to be much story or anything else.
Mathew Brett Wharton

In this fanciful animated film, we are taken on a journey aboard a train that surpasses any other train ride, as we travel to the North Pole.  A little boy, who has lost his faith in Christmas, is picked up along the way to join other children who will meet Santa Claus.  Tom Hanks' character is the conductor, among others, and he keeps the action going . . . or, is it the train?  The Polar Express will take you there, as long as you believe.  Also, if you wish to own a Polar Express train, Lionel has created a few versions so you, too, can capture the Spirit of Christmas with your imagination.  This DVD will certainly take you on an unforgettable train ride to the center of your being as you, like that little boy, Believe in Christmas.

A boy, suspicious of Santas existence, dreams or hallucinates that a train has pulled up in front of his house on Christmas Eve.  When he investigates he meets a snarky conductor who doesnt care whether he boards this Polar Express, or not.  He does, or there wouldnt have been much of a movie.  At the next stop theres a poor boy also reluctant to board.  Christmas doesnt mean much to him because Santa has never visited his house.  But hes willing to go along for the ride.  The ride turns into a roller coaster experience that eventually takes them to their destination.  Do they really meet Santa or is this only an adventure that dreamer Dorothy could appreciate?  A bell holds the answer.

Artistically speaking, it is visually stunning.  The score, by Alan Silvestri, is lovely.  But.  The story is severely limited in scope and understanding of the holiday and children.  As for the motion-capture effect used on the people, it is, as others have observed, incredibly creepy and lifeless.  The eyes are troubling, the way their mouths don't work correctly is freaky and distracting.

First I will start by saying that I never give spoilers in any of my movie reviews. I keep it simple and say whether it is good or not.

I pretty much purchased this movie just to add another 3D title to my movie collection. So needless to say I had it for quite a while before ever viewing it. However after viewing this movie, We wish we had watched it sooner! Our entire family found the movie very well done. The story line was whimsical and at times a real treat. I would consider this to be a great movie for the entire family, including the very young ones. Also, this movie would be enjoyable any time of the year!
 The 3D aspect was done very well. I have seen better but this by no means was poor. There where a few times when the 3D was a little underwhelming and I may have noticed a slight ghosting here and there but all in all a pretty decent 3D rendering is what you can expect. Please keep on mind that not all 3D Televisions are made the same and some 3D TV's just aren't very good at displaying 3D. Luckily we have a good 3D TV that shows a great 3D image. So when a 3D movie is played on our television, it is a very special treat as we can expect it to play just about as good as most any theatre can provide us. I have a vast 3D collection and have viewed most of them, so you can trust my advice when I say that this 3D movie is one of the better ones available.

I will sum this review up with this advice. If you are at all on the fence about whether you should buy this movie or not, I would suggest you do, and enjoy it.

Are you tired of the classic Christmas Movies? Looking for a feature that encompasses the essence of believing? Polar Express is guaranteed to enrapture young kids to adults taking them on a journey filled with action, thriller, comedy, musical, mystery, family, and fantasy.  Polar Express is an amazing 1 hour and 39 minutes animated movie featuring the voices of Tom Hanks and Leslie Zemeckis. The storyline follows a young boy at the brink of debunking the essence of "Santa Clause." When all of sudden a magical train ride appears taking him on a journey of believing once again. The movie has an underlying theme of friendship, bravery, and caring. It is an excellent movie for the home and for the classroom.
Want to use it in your classroom? There are several paper based resources available that align to the movie.
This was my first time renting a movie using Amazon Video. I was hopeful and sceptic in the logistics of clicking "rent" and the variability of it playing without trouble the next day while in the classroom. But it worked amazingly-never freezing or lagging. I rented the movie for a fraction of the overall cost of purchasing. The rules stated I had 30 days to start watch, and 24 hours to finish once started.
This was no cause for concern. I purchased the movie the day before. Once in the classroom I was able to open Amazon.com and went straight to my rented videos. I began the movie with no problems. I even had to stop the video several times throughout the day and each time it resumed exactly where we stopped.
This was a wonderful experience renting form Amazon Movies and for the price it was an excellent and easy decision. I plan on using this for my family nights. Next on our list is Secret Life of Pets for $4.99. You can't beat $4.99 for two adults and multiple kids! And just think, you don't have to miss the movie when you need to use the restroom!!
Great resource for those family movie nights or classroom needs.

Place it in your video library, beside "It's A Wonderful Life" and "Miracle on 34th Street," movies that will please you and future viewers in all of the years to come.

I didn't watch the entire movie because I found the first part disturbing. The train conductor was so harsh with the children, and the children were directed into situations that I always warn my children to avoid - for example allowing an adult male to take them to an isolated place were "punishment" will be doled out. The dynamic of innocent children versus authoritative, excessively stern adult was really off putting to me. I was disappointed because this movie has so many fans and I was looking forward to an upbeat holiday flick.
I am not sure if I'll ever sit down to watch the movie all the way through but the rest of it will have to be pretty good to make up for the troubling portions in the beginning.

This is one of my favorite Christmas movies. I rented the movie last week for my 6 year old grandson to watch because I took him on the Chicago Union Station Polar Express Train. What an experience something he would never forget. When Santa came out and gave him a bell they talked. My grandson turned and looked at me he said Ma i will never forget this day or you. I about cried very touching. He remembered everything from the movie and noticed the same on the train. At the end of the ride he said Ma why didn't the train go to the North Pole. Priceless moment and something he and I will cherish

This is a great movie ruined by Tom Hanks. His ego said no one else could play the parts but him. A close examination of most of the characters shows you he dominates the characters. I am surprised he didn't play the female parts.
Like most movies someone forgets to keep the story making sense. They make it more about the scenes rather than a continuous story. Then they run out of time and have to rush the ending. Every version of this movie is a visual winner. If you get to watch it in 3D you see why 3D is awesome. If you know someone with 3D TV watch this movie. If that doesn't convince you the value of 3D TV then nothing will. Someone else could have played the parts and done an excellent job making it the movie it should have been. Someone please do a remake. Get other people to do the parts and show Mr. Hanks and his giant EGO that he isn't the only actor with talent.

Ever since, it's been one of the 4-5 Christmas movies we MUST watch every year.
Just got a new copy on Blu-Ray, and it's lovely (holds up even 12 years later).
Like others have said, you need to watch it all to take in the messages and appreciate it.
It's not rude, crude, or otherwise shocking in any fashion - just good fun and a positive message without being at all preachy.

Some movies stand the test of time - Tom Hanks no doubt has a lot to do with the charms of this movie and I hope one day my granddaughter watches it with her kids.

First saw this in IMAX upon release, no viewing since had ever topped that experience. Having owned the DVD and seen multiple times on TV, just didn't do this wonderful movie justice. Had been tempted to buy the standard Blu-Ray but never did, but upon seeing there was this 3D version, the price was right and figured it had to be an improvement over DVD.

And thankfully, it is! Having read some negative reviews on the 3D quality, I am my own judge on some things, plus you can't always take another's word for it. I have a 3D HDTV and 3D Blu-Ray player, and tend to try to buy movies which help make the most of the system, and I was very pleased to find so much of that original IMAX experience was captured here. Nothing could top that, of course, but this was right up there. Picture was clear as a bell, sound was terrific, and the 3D was fantastic.

I read about a previous 3D release that had come with some cheap cardboard glasses, this is NOT that version. You also get a ton of special features along with the standard 2D version, all on the same Blu-Ray disc. I guess there within lies my only complaint, is perhaps the entire 3D presentation would have benefited just that little bit more if it did not all have to share space on the one disc. But a pretty weak complaint otherwise.

I wish directors would understand that no grown up actor can naturally move like a child, so some of the scenes just looked forced since Tom Hanks provided the motions. Billy looked the most natural, but some things just can't be replicated by an adult. Caribou do not make that sound---elks do. And with the exception of the Michael Jeter elf, I found the elves the most annoying and not really attractive or charming in any way. I'm sure they were patterned after the people who worked on the film, but I would've preferred loveable jolly elves...especially if they are going to speak Yiddish then make them sweet, not obnoxious. Didn't need the Steven Tyler song or scene. Beautiful score, but the hobo character was creepy. We always skip the marionette sequence as it's just too much for young ones... love the hot chocolate scene! The best part of this movie is the utilization of "old time" Christmas music with Bing and Frank and Perry and the Andrews Sisters and Kate Smith etc... But kids want Santa to be fun and merry, not stiff and weird looking...couldn't they hire an actor who looked like Santa instead of Tom Hanks and his low voiced rendition? I feel the animators spent so much time on some details but forgot obvious ones like the fact that most children have a full set of eyelashes and people blink a lot compared to what these CG characters did. Children squirm and rub eyes and noses etc.. they are not as robotic as these "kids"... I think the falling snow and the train were the best animated things in the movie. Oh yes and the screaming engineer thing...all I can say is I thank God for the mute button!!!!

The Polar Express is a movie I have been searching for the past few years. Red box, Netflix, hulu, and the others never have it so this year I decided to purchase it. I looked at Best Buy, Walmart and other major resellers but the price here was unbeatable.  It is probably the first movie I have actually purchased in the past 5 years. I have such good memories watching it with my nephew growing up.  I am very excited to continue the tradition with my daughter next year.
This movie is a great buy for the whole family. And it is insanely reasonably priced on here. I highly suggest grabbing a bowl of popcorn and a mug of hot chocolate to enjoy this flick with the whole family. Let everyone wear their pajamas and put your phones away.
  The plot is deep enough that I think that each family member comes away from the movie with a different understanding and appreciation of the film. It is one that is deeper than most children can grasp but has a fun story of imagination. It is interesting to see what your loved ones take away from it. The colors and characters are beautiful. The movie brings up all different kinds of emotions and family dialogue.  You will get to remember the innocence of your childhood and recognize the milestones we have all passed growing up.
Enjoy a great cast and story line! Enjoy the time with the ones you love! Enjoy the true Christmas spirit year round with this great catch!

We loved this amazing movie. Especially my 8 year old. The good news is that you won't get tired of watching for at least the first 3 or 4 times each year. Unless they happen to be in the same day. 2 weeks into watching it daily, well then you might get a teensy bit of a tic by your right eye. But hey, admit it by that time most movies have you curled up in a corner wondering how you are going to bear it for another 2 weeks. This one piece of cake. At that point just hide it and promise a Polar Express Train Ride if they are good. (All hopped up and Christmas Cheer and the ubiquitous cookies and candy, parties and the promise of SANTA at the end... they will never make it the next 2 weeks being good so you can always find an excuse for not doing that one.) Tell them that you put it up so that the train ride would feel fresh and exciting instead of old and stale. You can get through the next 2 weeks in peace! Unless you happen to have "Barney" DVD's accessible then you are toast and may as well just check into a spa before you burn the house down or something drastic.

Full Disclosure: I talked Grandma into doing the Polar Express Ride so I got to keep my promise without having to pay for it.

Oh, if only for ghosting.....

It pains me to sit here knowing what I am about to write.
Warner Bros. was extremely gracious to send me a handful
of screeners to review knowing that I would be promoting
the good word of 3D on this forum.  However, when there
seems to be a problem with their initial batch of Blu-ray
releases I can't morally sit here and praise them to the
membership.

Their Imax release of Under The Sea looks terrific.
However, their Imax release of Space Station 3D is
lacking 3D in the first 3 minutes.  Now, The Polar Express
is exhibiting its own set of problems.  I sort of wonder
if anyone is doing some quality control here.

I'll get into all this in a moment....

I had to chuckle when I decided I was going to review
this title.  It took me back a few years to our last Home
Theater Forum meet.  The studio sent us an advance copy
of their initial 3D DVD release of The Polar Express and we
were showing it off in our demo room at the hotel.  Here
we were, a ragtag group of enthusiasts with cardboard
glasses on our faces admiring the cheesy 3D.

Boy, we have come a long way in a few short years.

Potentially, The Polar Express could have been a
flagship animated feature release for the studio on
the 3D format.  Originally filmed for Imax with
motion capture technology,  The Polar Express
translates beautifully to Blu-ray.  This was my
very first time watching the movie ever and I
was completely mesmerized by the film's charming
story and utterly stunning, realistic animation.

Transfer quality is as good as it gets.  I love
the film's warm, natural color palette consisting
primarily of blue and gold. Everything looks
perfect here.

The quality of the 3D separation is quite good
and very effective.  I have three favorite scenes
where I found the 3D effect to be most effective.
The first involves a floating train ticket.  Then
there's an exciting train descent into Glacier Gulch.
Finally, the entire Christmas Town square sequence
looks outstanding with all its brightly lit colors and
3D dimensionality.

There really aren't any "In Yo' Face" 3D moments.
Most of the material stays within the confines of
the screen with the exception of some minor screen
protruding from the fender of the train or the cap
of the train's hobo.

So here we have this immaculate, gorgeous holiday
eye-fest that would have looked perfect on 3D if not
for the fact that it is marred with ghosting problems.

It doesn't take long to notice the problem.  The first
scene where the young boy is lying in bed you see
double imaging within his face.  When this same boy
steps onto the Polar Express, takes his seat and meets
the black girl, you can see double imaging going on
within her facial features.  Some behind-the-head shots
reveal ghosting in the ears and along the hairline.
Watch the scene where the kids are being pulled up
inside Santa's sack and see how the ropes are
double-imaged.  In fact, there are moments that
I actually experienced eye strain from the amount
of ghosting and occasional blurriness.

The DTS-HD audio lovingly conveys Alan Silvestri's
score which is mostly prominent in the front channels.
This is a very bass-heavy audio track.  The oncoming
sound of The Polar Express literally shook my floor.

Like all of Warner's new 3D releases, The Polar
Express arrives in beautiful lenticular packaging.

CONCLUSION

Ultimately, I am disappointed.  This is such a beautiful
film and as much as the 3D enhanced my initial experience
with it, the ghosting issues became a big distraction.

I am sitting here hoping that someone can prove me
wrong on all the ghosting problems I see with this title.
The last thing I want to do is slam the studio for a title
like this.  However, up until now I have been seeing some
great 3D content with none of these problems.  I even
switched out my glasses for another pair just in case it
was a hardware issue.

The animation was creepy with the characters having eyes that looked more cat like than human.  All the additions to the story to make it long enough for a feature length film, completely changed the tenor of the original book, turning it from something sweet into something with a scary tone.  Do not recommend watching it with your child who liked the book.

Note ... this review is regarding the "Presented in 3D" version, not the movie itself.  The MOVIE is a 5+, but regarding this fake 3D, if we could give it a 0 we would.  I'd call it a scam at best!  To Amazon's credit, they pulled it from sale and also gave quick credit for returns.  It comes with goofy 1950's style cardboard glasses and do NOT function!  We have new Sony XBR 75" 4K/3D TV that gives the message that there is no 3D signal from the Sony 3D Blue Ray player ... and same from the Blue Ray player.  There is absolutely no way to adjust settings on the TV or player to make this scam disk function!

Love the movie but had to order another one to get the proper format. When I ordered this specific item, I selected and it was confirmed that I was purchasing the "Multi-format" version. Every other "multi-format" I've ordered in the past has had all versions of the film i.e., Blu Ray, Dvd, and digital hd download. So when I ordered this in multi-format, I expected the above trio of options to be included. It was also very misleading because there was a blu Ray option, dvd option, and multi-format option. So knowing what I had ordered in the past and the choices in front of me I chose the multi format and didn't think twice.  When it arrived it was just blu Ray so I couldn't play it in our car DVD player for my son when I had hoped to. I turned around and had to order the DVD version as well. I think there definitely needs to be some re-wording or more clarification to let the buyer/customer know for sure what they are purchasing. In the end I now have both the blu Ray and DVD and the movie itself is phenomenal and my 2 year old loves it!

I grew up loving the Polar Express, it was one of my favorite books and the movie is great.  Now I have a child of my own and loved introducing him to it this past Christmas.  He is three and just now interested in movies, he loves trains and I knew he would be a fan of the Polar Express.  I was right, he absolutely adores it and watched it about twice a day during the month of December.  We are burnt out on it now but I expect it will be a big part of our Christmas for years to come.
He loves the animation and the characters, especially the conductor.  He goes around singing the hot chocolate song and thinks its the funniest thing ever.  I love seeing the joy a simple movie can bring and I highly recommend this movie for families.  Its wholesome and sweet.

Polar Express
It's Christmas Eve and one boy is waiting up, pretending to be asleep. However, his faith is waning. Is Santa real? If so, will he be coming? He just isn't sure. Suddenly, train tracks appear in front of his house along with a steam locomotive powered train called Polar Express. The conductor has the boy on his passenger manifest. The boy asks where the train is going? "Why, to the North Pole, of course!" comes the conductor's response. The boy hesitates and the train begins to move, without him. The boy decides to jump on and so the journey begins.
We never find out most of the children's names, but the message of the film is more important to the screenwriter. To most people, seeing is believing, but sometimes, what you can't see is more real. About half the film is the adventure and mishaps of the train traveling to the North Pole and three children becoming friends.
We have our doubting boy, our self-assured, faith intact girl and a defeatist boy, who believed, but for whom, "Christmas just doesn't work out."
When they arrive at the North Pole, a bit of clumsiness sends our heroes on an adventure in the "behind the scenes" workings of the North Pole.
Lovely CG animation and a timeless story. Intended for young audiences, but adults like it too. Tom Hanks is the narrator and the conductor. A good film to make into a holiday tradition.

Unfortunately, I can't offer the love that this CG animated movie receives here from so many. As an somewhat early effort in animating realistic humans, it's a failure. Zemeckis's film comes from deep, deep in uncanny valleythe characters don't move correctly, the faces are stiff and unreal, the eyes unalive. But I still enjoy watching it as an entertaining spectacle. It is, in its way, just so exuberant and over-the-top the one can't take one's eyes off it. I could watch the hot chocolate pouring scene over and over again. Couldn't do that in live action. Mesmerizing. And the train's passage through ridiculous landscapes is impressive, to say the least. I don't buy into its saccharine Christmas sentimentality, but if it floats your boat, good for you. (Give me Geo. C. Scott's Christmas Carol or A Christmas Story or Tokyo Godfathers or Nightmare Before Christmas any day.)

I watched it again the last couple of nights after my wife went to bed; she can't stand to look at it, gives her "the creeps." And despite its failings, it's a unique and worthwhile filmin its strange, strange ways.

A terrifying voyage into the uncanny valley. The computer-animated characters here are beyond disturbing, and resemble animated store mannequins, with vastly frightening faces and movements. What it feels like is that Zemeckis was trying to do a George Lucas and make everything in CG "just because he could", and what's frustrating is that this might have made an excellent live-action film. Instead we're left with horrific video game characters in a cold, terrible world of ice and snow. Deeply disturbing.

Some of these reviews are misleading because they are talking about the 3D version that does not come with the red and blue glasses.  Apparently that version is much better than the one that has red/blue glasses in the case.  I got the latter, with the glasses, and it is heavily distorted with a ghost image and is unwatchable.  The movie titled "The Polar Express presented in 3-D" is the version you want to avoid.  The front cover shows a child standing in the snow looking at the front of the train.  The one I'm told is really 3-D has a child on top of the train as it goes over a bridge on the front cover.  It is titled "The Polar Express 3-D.

My child is a huge fan of the book and could not wait to watch this movie after we found it on Prime.  Not even halfway through, the look on his face changed from joy to fear.  Finally it got to the point where he asked us to stop the movie.  Being a fan of the book as well, I continued to watch the film, but could not finish.  As with any book turned into a movie, I expected some liberties to be taken, but the director/producer added such dark elements to the film that it destroyed the fundamental story line and overshadowed the spirit of Christmas. They took a beautiful story that my child and I know and love and turned it into a creepy, scary movie that I would not recommend to anyone.  What should have been a holiday movie classic in our home that the family could watch each season, will now be a movie that I hope my son will be able to forget.

The Polar Express delivered me all the way back to childhood and my own faith in Santa Claus at the age of five. I could not only hear the bells, I could see his sleigh in the night sky. Chris Van Allsburg is to be commended for writing an excellent fantasy and Tom Hanks for conducting the wonder tour to beat them all. The special effects are just outstanding, the story line credible and heartwarming. The characters are believable and utterly charming. The children depicted are our own. I would recommend this film to any and all who love Christmas and remember what it is to believe. The experience of watching makes you a participant, breathless to see what comes next. I can hardly wait to view it on IMAX and am taking my entire family, including seven grandchildren to the Tulsa Cinemark this season. Let's hope we see more of this quality venue in months and years to come.

This is a great movie that I enjoy watching with my three-year-old son.  It's about a boy who boards a magical Christmas train called the Polar Express on the night before Christmas.  He meets two new friends, one of whom has never received a gift from Santa Claus.  The main character has lost his belief in Santa, but is a kind soul who repeatedly helps the boy who hasn't gotten a gift from Santa.  The train takes all its passengers to the North Pole where they meet Santa after a ton of adventure.  It's based on a children's book by the same name I read in elementary school.  My son loves trains and Santa Claus, so he loves this book.  I enjoy the messages in the movie that my son is absorbing.  I'd recommend it for any child in the Santa Claus age range.

First, a few words about the movie and a word of explanation from your humble reviewer.  "The Polar Express" is one of those computer animations that try to look as photorealistic as possible in their representations of the actual world.  As a result, the humans appear almost but not quite real, like wax figures in a museum come to life.  I've never understood this concept, which makes everyone look kind of creepy to me.  If the studio figured to save money using the CGI animation technique as opposed to using live actors, saving money didn't work.  This 2004 production cost about $150,000,000 to make.  If the filmmakers figured the animation would provide some visual treats we couldn't otherwise get with live action, well, it doesn't do any more than one of today's comparable live-action CGI fantasies does.  If director Robert Zemeckis hoped to open our minds better to the world of imagination, the movie does so at cross purposes.  Would "Willy Wonka" or "Harry Potter" have been any better done in animation than in live action?  I doubt it.  When I finished watching "The Polar Express" the first time I saw it, I remember being left intrigued by the visuals but wondering why the filmmakers did it as a cartoon when they could have accomplished the same thing in live action without looking so...odd.  Therefore, please, temper my remarks with this preliminary grousing in mind; and understand that the animation will probably not bother most anyone else.

Zemeckis based the movie on a short, illustrated children's book by Chris Van Allsburg.  Zemeckis, as you know, is the fellow who gave us such spectacularly creative delights as "Back to the Future," "Who Framed Roger Rabbit," "Forrest Gump," and "Contact," all of them filled with fascinating characters and glorious visual sights.  In "Polar Express," however, the director stretches (an unkinder soul would say bloats) a simple story idea with so many visual effects that some of the characters get rather lost in the proceedings.

The animation technique produces varied results.  The scenery and surroundings are exquisite, imaginatively rendered in every detail, especially in high def, often looking like one of those Christmas globes with the snow swirling around inside; and from everything I can ascertain, the animation does a good job capturing the look and feel of the paintings in Van Allsburg's book.  It's the people who inhabit this world who look artificial in a spooky sort of way.  The filmmaking process that Zemeckis used requires live actors to perform their roles and then computer animators to duplicate their actions.  It's the modern equivalent of the early rotoscoping done by pioneer animators in the days of silent films.  Although it's quite a bit more advanced now, the basic idea is the same.  What I always have to ask, though, is if live actors perform the parts, why not make it a live-action movie?  What more does animation do to make something a fantasy?  Is the mere act of watching drawings instead of real people oblige us to believe all the more in a film's make-believe?  Well, it may, and if it works for you, more power to the filmmaking.

The plot, what little there is of it, concerns a young boy at an age where he's about to lose his belief in Santa Claus and the magic of Christmas.  In this most crucial year of his life, the Polar Express, Santa's personal train, shows up at his doorstep one Christmas Eve to convince him there really is a Santa.  Other children of a similar age and with similar feelings of disbelief fill the train.  From here, the movie offers a sweet and moving fable of regaining (or retaining) one's faith in the Christmas spirit, as the boy learns to be kind to other people and never lose his power of imagination.  No complaints here.

Tom Hanks stars in the movie, and stars in the movie, and stars in the movie.  He is the voice behind most of the main characters, which works well for several reasons.  First, he's a fine actor and provides good voice characterizations for, among others, the boy's father, the train conductor, a mysterious hobo, and Santa himself.  Second, having Hanks voice so many of the characters makes it feel all the more like storybook time, as though one person alone were telling the tale; which, in fact is the case, as Hanks also voices the boy grown up, looking back on his own childhood.

I enjoyed the other characters voices as well, all of them ably, if not always so colorfully, voiced:  Nona Gaye as a little girl that the boy befriends; Leslie Zemeckis as the boy's sister Sarah; Peter Scolari as a shy, lonely boy; and, best of all, Eddie Deezen as an annoying, know-it-all kid.  You'll recognize Deezen's distinctive voice instantly from things like "1941" and "WarGames."  He practically saves the day by being the most unique and entertaining voice of all the characters in the movie.  Every time he appears, the movie livens up.

The action of the story takes places almost entirely on the train and then at the North Pole in a series of short episodes.  These brief segments involve the boy in various adventures, none of which are particularly involving because of their brevity.  After a somewhat slow start, the episodes begin to come along rather quickly, and it's shortly afterwards that we realize there's not going to be much more to it than that; nothing lasts long enough to develop much tension, and there aren't many clear transitions between events to sustain an engrossing story line.

Zemeckis possibly intended the rapid succession of incidents to remind us of a child's dream, because certainly it never induces us to believe the boy is awake while all this is going on.  Nevertheless, I found my mind wandering at times, maybe indicating I'm not a child anymore.

Several of the segments have a rousing spirit, though, and they display a verve sometimes lacking in the rest of the film.  There is a scene with dancing waiters and a song, "Hot Chocolate," that comes alive in an energetic, Monty Pythonesque way; there's a stunning shot of an eagle flying through a gorge that is lovely enough to frame; there's a sequence with the train sliding down a roller-coaster track and then slipping sideways on an expanse of ice that is really quite harrowing; and there is a passage set in a roomful of puppets that is scary in the way only puppets and marionettes can be scary.

But offsetting these instances of beauty and excitement are too many songs that seem less than memorable ("Believe" being the main one); too much background music that tries to be uplifting and inspirational and comes off gushy; too much pacing that is awkward and herky-jerky; too much that should be surreal that only seems tedious; too much that is simply sentimental; and too little storyline to tie it all together.

The moviemakers might better have called the film "The Bipolar Express," with so much that is sweet and light on the one hand and so much that is tiring and humdrum on the other.  I liked the movie's first half a lot; I found the second half going on and on rather slowly.  Although I have no doubt most kids and many adults will love it, this Scrooge came away with somewhat mixed feelings.

Video:
My friend and fellow movie critic Eddie Feng and I once discussed two issues related to this film.  Namely, (1) the inability of animators to realize fully the nuances of real human faces and (2) the relative ease in capturing animated characters on disc as compared to capturing the subtleties of human faces.  The result is that "The Polar Express" looks more realistic than most animated movies but not quite realistic enough to pass for the real thing.  Nevertheless, like it or not, it shows up gloriously in 2-D high definition.

However, since the disc contains both a 2-D and a 3-D version of the movie and since the 3-D is the main attraction here, let's start with that format first, the special 3-D process rendered by Sony Pictures Imageworks.  Because "The Polar Express" is one of the Wife-O-Meter's favorite films, she was anxious to watch it in its new three-dimensional trappings.  So, we dutifully put on the red-and-blue 3-D glasses and attempted to enjoy the picture.  No dice.  The same thing happened that I had experienced with previous 3-D films.  I wear eyeglasses for distance, and the 3-D cardboard-and-cellophane frames would not fit comfortably over or under my regular glasses.  I resorted to cutting one pair of 3-D glasses apart and taping them to my own glasses, but it still didn't work.  The 3-D glasses were always uncomfortable, and the 3-D picture was always out of focus, with quite a bit of ghosting going on.  The Wife-O-Meter fared no better.  She doesn't wear glasses, but she has had her eyes surgically corrected, with one eye adjusted for reading and one for distance.  She could never focus on the 3-D picture, always coming up with two different images slightly apart.

Worse still, in 3-D neither of us saw the brilliant colors we had become used to in the 2-D editions.  Instead, we found a dull sheen, like a veil, over the hues.  After fifteen or twenty minutes we both agreed to give up on the ghosting effects and the veiled colors, and we watched the movie in regular 2-D.

One could hardly fault any part of the Blu-ray 2-D presentation.  The video engineers retained the movie's 2.40:1 widescreen dimensions in a 1080p, VC-1 transfer that looks identical to the HD DVD encode.  (An insider friend told me it is, indeed, the same encode.)  The colors are deep and the overall focus is as sharp as it can be.  More important, the colors are extremely natural (for a cartoon or for real life), rich and lush, with intense black levels.  Believe me, like its HD-DVD counterpart, the Blu-ray picture is a joy to watch, and my Video rating below reflects my reaction to the 2-D version only.

Audio:
If there is any improvement in the Blu-ray edition over the HD DVD, it is in the audio.  Where the HD DVD used Dolby Digital Plus 5.1, the Blu-ray uses Dolby TrueHD, a genuine lossless codec.  There is a tremendously deep, taut, room-shaking bass, combined with ultrawide dynamics for a sometimes awesome sonic experience.  Just wait until Santa's train thunders into your listening area.  The effect is enough to rattle the rafters.  The fact is, the disc's TrueHD sound is just as good as the video, with an impact so strong it'll blow your hair back.  What's more, the sound is clear and clean, with well-integrated dialogue and sonic effects.  It's an impressive soundtrack for an impressive audiovisual presentation.

Note:  By default, the disc also includes a regular Dolby Digital 5.1 track.  Remember to select TrueHD when you begin watching the film.

Extras:
As I found with the previous SD and HD editions, the extras are only so-so, again with no audio commentary.  I suppose Warners figure the main bonus items this time are the two movie formats, 2-D and 3-D, on the same disc, along with the four pairs of 3-D glasses.

The other extras begin with a four-minute segment, "You Look Familiar: The Many Polar Faces of Tom Hanks," explaining why Hanks played so many roles in the film.  Then there's a five-minute bit, "True Inspirations: An Author's Adventure," profiling the work of author and artist Chris Van Allsburg; followed by four minutes taking us "Behind the Scenes of 'Believe'" and into the recording studio.

After that, we find the main documentary, "A Genuine Ticket to Ride," lasting about twenty-five minutes and covering the usual topics:  "Performance Capture," "Virtual Camera," "Hair and Wardrobe," "Creating the North Pole," and "Music"; and a new "Flurry of Effects" gallery, about eight minutes of motion-capture sessions comparing the live-action preliminaries with the final animation; followed by four minutes of singer Josh Groban performing the song "Believe" at the Greek Theatre.

Finally, there are about two minutes of Christmas memories, "Meet the Snow Angels," reminiscences from various of the filmmakers; plus a seven-minute, never-before-seen deleted musical scene with Smokey and Steamer, the train's engineers; and a "THQ" PC game demo with two playable levels.  The disc also has twenty-four scene selections; English, French, Spanish, and Dutch spoken languages; French, Spanish, and Dutch subtitles; and English captions for the hearing impaired.

A final added incentive:  The keep case comes housed in a colorful slipcover with a 3-D holographic picture on the cover.  Very attractive.

Parting Thoughts:
As a counterbalance to my curmudgeonly reactions, I would remind you that the Wife-O-Meter thinks very highly of this movie.  She feels the stop-and-go action is much like the way a child thinks, the colors, excitement, and adventure are right up a child's alley, the themes are moving, and the characters are fun.  She has persuaded me that children should love it as much as she does.  It undoubtedly is an enchanting movie for children, and it even began to grow on this cranky adult after the third or fourth viewing.

Now, indulge me a moment longer.  Strangely, perhaps, I saw many similarities in this film and, of all things, Steven Spielberg's "1941."  What's that, you say?  Yes, in the movie's episodic construction, its fitful, irregular execution, its musical interludes and march music, its Eddie Deezen character, and its elaborate special effects, it reminded me of Spielberg; which may be no coincidence given that Zemeckis worked extensively with Spielberg early in his career and was a wizard at special effects.  And like "1941" the sum of the many elements in "The Polar Express" don't quite add up to as much as they should.

Nonetheless,  as the Conductor says, "One thing about trains:  It doesn't matter where they're going; what matters is deciding to get on."  If you can believe strongly enough, you can do anything or be anything you want.  It's hard to knock so winsome and earnest a notion, and even though neither the Wife-O-Meter nor I liked the 3-D version very much, we positively loved the Blu-ray's 2-D picture and sound.

If you are used to the kind of 3D experience you see in IMAX or regular movie theaters, this DVD is not up to that level. This uses anaglyphic 3D, which uses glasses with blue and red lenses (not polarized or active shutter technology). If you want the Polar Express disk that works with your high end 3D projector or TV, that would be a specific, high-end type of 3D blu-ray disk, which costs two or three times the cost of the DVD or 2D blu-ray disks of this same film. This review is for the DVD 3D version of the film.

This DVD is for those who want a 3D version of Polar Express without paying hundreds of dollars for all that high-end 3D equipment. It isn't as good as the more expensive 3D blu-ray and the system that goes with that, but it is a lot cheaper, because this DVD and the cheap colored glasses that go with it, will work on a regular 2D TV, computer monitor, or 2D projector.

It is also pretty inexpensive to buy lots of those cheap, cardboard blue-red glasses for showing this film in 3D to large groups, which is why I bought it.

As for the film itself. It has become kind of a Christmas classic. Personally, I can take it or leave it. My Christmas favorites are "Miracle on 34th Street," "The Santa Clause" and "Love Actually."

My favorite Christmas movie. I know, the animation of the character's faces wasn't incredible, but the human animation never seemed creepy to me, just a little rough and I can look past that. There are some parts of the movie that I can see classified as creepy though, although these same scenes are very magical and heartwarming at the same time - trudging through the empyty 1950's style Christmas city, the hobo, the lost toys car, etc.

The only part I really loathed was the short scene with the Steven Tyler elf and the Aerosmith Christmas song. This had nothing to do with the 1950's them or any other theme in the movie and I have absolutely no idea why this was in there.

This message is not to encourage lies, it is about encouraging faith and have faith no matter what background you came from. The message is also not about giving gifts, the gift at the end is just symbolism for the spirit of Christmas.

I know it's probably difficult to make a feature length movie out of a short children's book. And I understand that in that situation the director needs to fill an hour and a half with content so there will be filler. It just seems that all of the filler in this movie is the plot finding ways to put children in peril. While the obvious filler made me pretty bored, the constant children in peril scared my children. Also, the cold dead eyes of all the characters from the motion capture animation don't help either. The kids enjoyed some of the movie and like to sing the Hot Chocolate song. The final scenes are very nice and heartwarming as well.

This is a wonderful story for both children and adults.  And if you're a train lover, you're really in for a treat!  Based on a lovely book, this movie adds in a few additional details to make it feature-length, but they're all great.  It has become a tradition in my first grade class to read the story, work on activities surrounding the story, and culminate our semester with Polar Express Day, where children "board the train" to watch the movie while sipping hot chocolate and eating cinnamon toast.  What a wonderful last day before we take a break for the holidays!  This year, I purchased an additional copy for a coworker as a gift.  He was thrilled to have it, as he reads the book to his class of first graders as well.

I have always appreciated the writings Chris Van Allsburg.  His Polar Express is an especially beautifully told and illustrated tale.  The movie based on that book by Robert Zemeckis is a brilliant enhancement of the original story.  It has a magic in it that has captured children all the world over.  And that is especially true of our four year old grandson.
I purchased a digital version, since our DVD version was watched so many times over the years that it was scratched beyond repair.  One of the best holiday movies ever made!

This is a nice holiday movie about the magic of Christmas and the importance of believing even when the logical side of your mind tells you not to. The movie expands on the simple (but lovely) story by Chris Van Allsburg about the journey to the Notrth Pole undertaken by a boy who is no longer sure that he believes in Santa Claus. I enjoyed watching with my children (ages 13 and 8).  We have a very small TV, but I'm guessing it would be even more fun with a large screen, as some of the train sequences are like a roller coaster ride. Having never stopped believing myself,  I highly recommend it!

People looking for the latest in 3D Pixar/Dreamworks technology will probably be disappointed. The graphics work well for the period this was created in but pale in comparison to more modern films of today, but don't let that stop you from enjoying a solid holiday treat.

Great children's movie that focuses on the magic of Christmas.  There are no religious references, so if that is important to you, then this may not be your movie.  However, if you want a feel-good movie that is magical and beautiful, this is your film.  There are intense moments, which would scare my children a little bit when they were younger.  Now that they are older and on the cusp of "not believing," I hope it allows them to believe in that magic for a lifetime...because it is always there.
great movie

This is such a heart warming story!  I love the visual enjoyment of how they made the movie.  I've been reading the story to kids for many years and this year I even became an Elf on our local Polar Express.  Believing in the magic of Christmas is something some people tend to lose as they get older.  The story, and movie, just goes to show that doesn't have to happen. I've never cared much for 3D. I usually think it's distracting and gimmicky. But I bought an AMAZING Samsung F8500 plasma several months ago, and it came with 6 pairs of glasses, so I wanted to at least try it at some point. I just wasn't going to go out of my way to do so. I don't even buy movies very often anymore, but this 3D blu-ray was pretty reasonable, and even though my kids are getting a little older, the Polar Express is still enjoyable to watch once a year. I figured why not.

We watched it this past weekend, and everybody really enjoyed it. If you like this movie, I highly recommend this version. The 3D isn't an afterthoughtit's clear that much of the movie was made with 3D in mindand it's well done. I was pleasantly surprised with how much I enjoyed the 3D element. It added a depth and a richness that was a big improvement over the standard HD version (or at least that was my conclusion after re-watching the 2D version of a couple of scenes).

Does that mean I'm now a 3D convert and that I'm going to go out and start seeking out 3D content? No, but I am a fan of it for this movie, and I am more inclined to give 3D a chance in the future. The Catch 22 for 3D is that there really aren't any rentable or streamable titles, and buying the 3D version usually comes at a much higher price...making it a no go. But when this feature is included for a reasonable price as it is here, it's another story.

Even if you don't care about 3D, the other reason to get this disc is for the fantastic high resolution audio. The dynamic music, the train noises, etc are really something special when played on good surround system. Turn it way up!

The Polar Express is an excellent animated film based on the book of the same name. This film however, goes far beyond the idea of the book.  The original book is an excellently animated scroll with an easy to follow story for smaller children.  It ends with the protagonist getting a bell from Santa.  The bell can ring, but it's tone is only heard by children who believe in Santa.

This movie is a bit like a dream.  The characters are never named, one must look at the credits to see Hero Boy and Hero Girl, etc.  The Polar Express pulls in to the front of Hero Boy's house and the conductor, excellently played by Tom Hanks convinces the boy to get on.  Again, there is a sort of magical dream-like quality to this, the boy goes into the snow of a dark Mid-Western winter night in only a bathrobe and PJ's and he doesn't freeze.  This is a leap of faith, for we know that Hero Boy is very much a doubter.  He has come to seriously question his belief in Santa Claus and is on the verge of cynicism.

Because of the unreliableness of dream vs. reality,the entire trip has a sort of exaggerated strangeness to it.  The conductor and another child cross railway cars easily and yet when our protagonist attempts to follow, the passageway between cars has changed to an impassible, outside connection with the couplings exposed. In another surreal sequence, the Hero walks above the railway cars, calf-deep in snow where he meets a ghost hobo.  Like in a dream, time itself passes in an illogical way, five minutes to Midnight take much longer than they should.  The Polar Express continues on, true to the book, going over mountains and valleys, nearly touching the moon, and finally arriving at the North Pole.  One never really knows if this is all a dream, or something like a prophecy which occurrs during sleep.  It all adds to the mystery of the film.  Indeed the Hero wakes in his accurately represented, Mid-Western home seemingly refreshed.

The North Pole, and Santa's Workshop have an Edwardian feel to them.  It turns out that the producers made the town look like the Pullman workshop at the turn of the century.  Indeed there is something quite comforting about the two decades before the Great War.  Walt Disney made an entire series of films about Edwardian times-there is a sort of nostalgia.  What's the quote, "Nobody born after 1914 really knows what it's like to be happy."  Santa's workshop is an excellent example of this nostalgic, child-like wonder at a well run society where progress is the norm and there is prosperity for all.

Additionally, the movie uses an excellent series of dilemmas to make the story interesting, the train goes off the track, the small boy trips trying to get on the train, a ticket gets lost, caribou block the tracks, there are elf skydivers who help the lighter-than-air craft land the packages on the sleigh.  The gadgets and things in the North Pole are all excellent and creative.  The train-ride is like a roller coaster ride.  Some of the scenes are so intense small children might become, temporarily, frightened.

The use of bells as a device to show faith is pretty excellent too.  There is something wholly theological about Santa himself.  Many people view the jolly old elf as a sort of secular, anti-Jesus (I don't wish to say anti-Christ) who clouds the "true meaning of Christmas."  Perhaps, but Santa is very likely the modern expression of the god Woden and Christmas a continuing celebration of the birth of Mithras and the festival of Saturnalia.  Perhaps the meaning of the movie is to believe...in the mythological truths that spring from the deepest of roots.

One of the best movies I've ever seen. This timeless and classic tale takes struggles from all walks of life and animates them on a journey to the North Pole. It teaches how to depend on others, how to be a part of a family where none of us have it all, but all of us add something important, where what we can trust in is love and acceptance. And we see how this is made possible if we come to believe. We are shown that the journey is more important than the goal.

Morals lie deep beneath the animated surface. The hero shows us doubt - for him, doubt in Santa, for us, doubt in anything that requires faith where all the facts don't support what we've been told. He has the fantastic opportunity to go into a world where the truth is shown to him, the importance here being that since most of us don't get this chance, we can learn from his experience.

He meets a girl who is loving and welcoming and befriends the boy throughout his journey. She is caring and stays by him through thick and thin. She is assertive and proactive, she is outgoing and is willing to reach out fearlessly, to touch and hug another human being in need, likely the result of a loving and supportive family or spiritual life. She has received, and therefore can give and keep giving. She is given the title of one who can be a leader because these are the traits that people will follow.

He next meets a young boy who seems to know it all. More than likely, he has been taught to believe his is ignorant and therefore tries to prove the opposite by learning random facts and showing his accomplishments. He is screaming for acceptance and respect, and doesn't realize it. At the end, his lesson is to learn, but not to learn in order to prove intelligence, rather to learn that he is already intelligent and thereby improve his true self esteem.

And then we meet the lonely little boy who is filled with fear and lonliness. From a family he cannot rely on, his attitude extends to all people and he will not interact with others as they might reject or humiliate him. Christmas, or love, has never "worked out" for him. But on the journey he is set with others who are dependable and surround him with love. In the end, he learns that there are people you can count on and he experiences their love and acceptance. He learns to believe in others.

We are basically shown that we need each other, that we don't all have the same strengths and together we are much stronger than apart. We don't have all we need to live alone, and we will always fall into times of need. It is our bonds with others that gives us what we lack and makes us more whole and complete. As the journey ends, the conductor, the one who brings the group together and keeps them together until their lessons are learned, says, "One thing about trains (aka where people gather) it doesn't matter where they are going (aka you don't know what's ahead), what matters is deciding to get on (aka being a meaningful part of a supportive group). Give when you can, take when you need. Believe that others will be there for you, and they will be, if you believe you are there for them. This story does a great job of showing that.

Transparently forced Christmas "magic" that can't even lean on its CG visuals for support. Despite the wide variety of gaudy, jolly ghosts, elves and Christmas nicknacks flittering about the screen, this movie has no spirit, no zeal, no life. It sure goes through the motions, producing overly-familiar shapes, sounds and colors by the shovelful, but that never translates to more real emotion than the pajama section of a Sears catalog. It's mostly a one-man show, with Tom Hanks providing voices for a good ninety percent of the cast, but he's unable to work any holiday miracles with such flat source material. The wealth of bad, empty computer graphics do the film no favors, either, somehow managing to bridge the gap between hollow marionettes and the unnerving denizens of the uncanny valley. A desperate effort to join the endless parade of holiday classics, it's a noble-minded (but incompetent) talent flush.

Like love and marriage, Christmas and trains go together, or did so for my post-WWII generation. The Polar Express conjures up a number of familiar images to me: trains, snowy nights, and red-brick cities. The year I moved to Akron, Ohio, Chris Van Allsburg's book was published. It was Christmastime and red-brick Akron was blanketed in snow, and a rail-line ran through the center of the city. I half-expected to see a steam locomotive pull up at any moment. I didn't buy the book, but I did see the movie in the theater, and bought the DVD when it came out. While a bit short on story, what "The Polar Express" does well is capture a child's wonder of Christmas.

It's a story about growing up, but not growing old. The boy knows there's no Santa. He even checks out the encyclopedia on the North Pole which tells him there's no life on it. But the train comes and he doesn't know what to make of it. He decides to get on after Hank's character explains what's going on. He sees all the other children and how excited they are about going to see Santa. The train ride is wildly exciting . I don't want to give out spoiler alerts here. Of course they reach the North Pole and there are thousands of elves running about. The children get off the train to join them. Everyone's waiting for Santa Claus to appear. He's going to choose one of the kids to receive the first gift of the season. Unfortunately one of the kids doesn't want to join because "Christmas doesn't work out for me". The main boy who's made friends with a girl talk him into going with them to join the rest of the group. As they're about to get off the train, it starts to move and takes them on a crazy ride through town. They discover how the good & bad lists are created and how the presents get into Santa's bag. Eventually they make their way back to the big event where Santa finally shows up. This is a big moment for the boy who didn't believe. Santa picks a child (no spoiler alert here) and then the party begins. Santa leaves for the ride around the world. The children, having had the time of their lives, board the train back home very tired. The present that the child picked gets lost. This gift had so much meaning to the child and he/she is terribly upset because there's a hole in the pocket of the robe where it fell out of. The next morning, gifts are waiting and the true meaning of believing comes to light.

IMHO, this is one fantastic movie. It brings back fond memories (for many) of the Holiday Season from years ago. Understand however that this is about the Santa Clause version of Christmas with almost no religious content whatsoever. Some took umbrage at this fact but if you can overlook that, I expect you will love this movie. Tom Hanks does his usual excellent work voicing several of the characters and the highly accurate depiction of the mechanics of the train will delight, should you be a rail buff. The overall artwork is great altho some have complained that the characters look a little too real and that seemed to make them a bit uneasy. Not me. The message is pure and simple: ya gotta believe in Santa or none of the "magic" will happen. Keep close watch at the very end to catch the last bit of that magic.

HTH,
Garth

I pretty much never watch a movie on Amazon without first reading the reviews, and in seeing all of the 5 star reviews, I was thinking this was going to be Toy Story in Christmas land.  Well, I ran into some big problems with it as soon as the "hot chocolate" section of the film hit.  It was my first hint there would be a lot of songs and weird animation, none of it with any meaning whatsoever. I can't help but find myself left wondering what in the world these other people were watching.  It seems like 2/3rds of the animation is about things flying just out of the reach of people (the ticket, the pin, the ticket, the pin... Oh my word, repetitive nothingness much?).  I realize lots of people are calling this a Christmas classic, but I really have to wonder, did these people watch any of the old claymation Christmas Specials? Because, in THOSE films, things happened.  There were actions, and consequences to those actions. Not so much in this one.

The film seemed so meaningless that when I saw the train tracks going on 'the steepest slope ever" I thought to myself "OHHHHHHHH..... so Disney wants to build a ride called the Polar Express, and base it on the movie."  I don't know if they did build a ride, but the movie went from pointless sub plot to pointless sub-plot.  I hate that I hated it.  I so wanted to like it.  It's just, well, nothing happened.  There were no consequences behind any of the actions, and Tom Hanks obviously tried his heart out, but to me, it was sooooo obvious it was Tom Hanks, whenever I saw the conductor, I saw Tom Hanks, and not a character, and that's a death knell for ANY film, but is DOUBLY bad when it's an animated film.

Still, other people loved it to which I can only say, "I don't know why."  I feel like I might be the only person who didn't get whatever it was they were going for, and I'm giving it one star NOT because of the bad 3-D (I watched it for free in Hi-Def on Amazon Prime in 2D), but rather because it was just bad.

This is a 3D showcase with excellent sound and 3D that's good but not as good as it appeared in the Imax theater where I first saw the movie.

The sound comes into play most effectively when the train arrives.  With a good home theater, that train will shake the house.  It's a good effect early in the movie.

Disappointing was the 3D itself.  The depth was fine but the 3D was  -- on the blu-ray, not the theater -- reluctant to break much past the plane of the TV's surface.

Tom Hanks plays several of the roles -- an idea that turns out to have been better on paper than it turned out to be.  The story and some of his performances were . . . well, more creepy than endearing.

Story -- 3 Stars
Sound - 5 Stars
Performances - 3 Stars
3D effects -- 4 Stars.
Young child's likely reaction -- restlessness.

The movie does have its excellent moments -- the arrival of the train, the tracking of a wayward train ticket as it brings you on a pretty good roller coaster ride, the high-energy dance number as hot chocolate is served to the children, and a walk on the train's roof during a snow storm.

Yup it has its ups and downs -- for better and for worse.

As often as I try, I simply cannot understand the hype for this overrated, so-called classic. The book may have been a treat (I've not read it), the movie is a trick. Too much Hanks and too much repetition of action thinly disguised as something different. Calling it a Christmas classic is a disservice to both the word "classic" and the true meaning of Christmas. It is more an ode to toys, toys and more toys and mind numbing roller coaster rides called action.

For many of us, "The Polar Express" was probably the first book we ever managed to read on our own. The story is interesting, the perspective is inspired, and the subject matter is timeless.  While the movie does take some liberties with the book (there's a lot that happens in the movie that does not occur in the book), the story matter stays fairly true to its origins. The soundtrack is wonderful, the visuals are beautiful, and the memories of my childhood Christmases that it provoked are priceless. I would highly recommend this movie not only for children, but also for adults who are stressed out around the holidays and need to take a step back and remember when you too could hear the bell ring...

This review reflects the anaglyph 3D technology version entitled "The Polar Express Presented in 3-D".

Amazon is selling two 3D versions of "The Polar Express": the modern Blu-ray 3D version entitled "The Polar Express 3D" requiring a 3D Blu-ray player, and the ancient anaglyph 3D technology version entitled "The Polar Express Presented in 3-D". I was unfortunate to have purchased the latter. Impossible to watch. Amazon's "Product Alert" should be more noticeable. The film itself? Can't say.
One of the favorite movies for Christmas, I love the story, kids are watch it all the time, my husband love 3D in this movie.
This move is great for watching by yourself or with the family.  I am glad I am able to share this movie with mine.

I remember seeing this movie when it came out.  I had a 5 yr old at the time.  It was very disappointing.  I cannot understand how 1,000+ reviewers don't see how this is a HORRIBLE children's film.  My husband purchased the Blue Ray 3-D DVD awhile back so I saw it again with my 9-year-old daughter recently.  Even she agreed it was a lousy and weird Christmas movie.  The settings are desolate.  There are many instances of peril.  (Peril in movies could be fun or have a purpose, there was no purpose for it here.)  There is an abandoned North Pole that the children are walking through.  Other than the conductor (Tom Hanks) who is mean to children, there is not one loving adult in sight.  The children are completely abandoned.  Wait, I forgot there is a creepy Hobo on the train who is actually a ghost. The Hot Chocolate song sung by Tom Hanks has to be one of the worst songs ever on film.  The animation is atrocious in this particular scene because the waiters looks like robots.  How is this a children's film?  The original book was beautiful, but there was a lot of artistic license taken and the results are simply depressing.  I'm throwing my copy in the trash.  Why would I give this to another family?
I did not get what I expected. Instead of  two dvds I got just one. I returned the item and got reinversed.

I choose this DVD for my grandson who has Spinal MUsculour Atrophy, this is one of his favorite movies. He really enjoys watching this DVD, so happy that it is available for him to watch anytime he wants. I really appreciate the short time it took for it to arrive at my home, since I wanted to give it to him for his birthday. I would recommend to anyone to order , from ur company as u r really r dependable in getting orders out in a fast time!

We received a 3D TV for Christmas, and The Polar Express is one of our favorite movies to watch as the holidays approach. While we don't plan to replace every DVD or Blu-ray with a 3D version, this movie was made witt 3D in mind from the very beginning.  If you have the cables that can transmit the 3D signal, a blu-ray or DVD player that plays 3D and a TV capable of displaying the 3D signal, then this Blu-ray combo pack is a must have!

It's now one of my favorite Christmas films (the music is great, too).  I prefer Christmas movies that have more of a religious slant, but this one movie is an exception.

Again, one of my favorite Christmas music. If you're not feeling the Christmas Spirit, this is a great movie to help boost your mood! 5 stars!

My grandson is two years old. He loves trains, trucks, cars and planes. This is now his favorite movie. My daughter and her husband have watched "Thomas & Friends" every day for the last six months. So I looked through the listings on Amazon to find a suitable movie for him and discovered "Polar Express." This terrific family film gave his parents a breather from their son's favorite show, which I bought on video. More importantly, it creates a sense of wonder in the viewer and features amazing work by Tom Hanks. He plays multiple animated characters. There is never a dull moment. "Polar Express" is certain to become a Christmas classic.
My son absolutely loves this movie.  It gives me so much enjoyment to see how happy he is when he watches it.
This is a one of a kind movie.  I new I would buy it the day I watched it.  Fantastic

This is a great movie suitable for young and adults.  The music is fantastic and the 3D effect is so good that my 5 year old grandson was trying to reach out for the elves and Santa.  I would recommend it to anyone especially for the Christmas festive season.

There is a disclaimer stating that there is no need for a 3D TV and BluRay player - that is not the issue. I do have a 3D Tv and 3D bluRay player - the issue is that the dvd does not play the 3D disc in 3D using either the glasses that came with the 3D TV nor will it play in 3D with the glasses included with the movie disc.

It is that "lack of information" not provided by the seller that I rated a 1 star.

I bought this because my kids and I love this movie but its hard to watch because you see double when using the glasses with the 3D disc..I am glad that it came with a regular dvd so at least we can happily watch it without the glasses

My wife used this in her classroom and was disappointed in the poor quality of the sound track.  She used it on the same player she used for other videos in the recent past but didn't have the same issue with the other videos.  We have the Bluray version at home that I intend to play and compare it for her as we play this most recent wide screen version.
I love this movie and it looks even better on blu ray. This is a great addition to my collection.
I would reccommend this movie to anyone that needs to believe there is magic in the world. Excellent movie from the creator of Back to the Future- take this journey!
Entertaining for both child and adult. My son is 4 and he really enjoyed the movie. We watched it numerous of times.

Awesome Christmas movie, don't miss this one!
Fast shipping, good quality, just as described !!
Great movie for the entire family !

The Polar Express was made for 3d and things really seem to pop.  If you have a 3d tv and player you will not be disappointed with this Christmas Classic.  Make a tradition of sitting with the family and watching this in 3d.

I purchased another copy because my Grandson is wearing out the other one!  That is his favorite movie and he watches it year-round!  Plus, I didn't have Blu-Ray DVD. It's clarity is amazing and there's other features on it that I enjoyed. Thanks Amazon!
Bought this for my grandson who is 9 years old. He really enjoyed watching it. Tom Hanks fantastic as usual.
This is my son's favorite movie on earth.  A Christmas favorite for all of us.  So glad to have it as part of our collection.
I already gave it fir a Christmas present, to a five year old boy. He loves it very much. I think he has watched it five times.

This was purchased as a gift for my best friend, and it is her favorite holiday movie. Great addition to your holiday movie collection!

There are so many movies that recycle the same old fairy tales, it is nice to find one that is original.  The story is fresh, and makes me believe, along with the children.
I am amazed every time I see this movie by the detail work. The animation was done over real actors, so it takes getting used to. Tom Hanks plays several characters, and is amazing. Will watch again next Christmas, it has become a family tradition !
I LOVE THE MOVIE.  WATCH IT EVERY YEAR JUST BEFORE CHRISTMAS.  ORDERED IT FOR MY GRANDSON WHO IS 7 AND HE NEVER SAW IT UNTIL 2013.  HE LOVED THE MOVIE TOO.

This movie is absolutely spectacular.  If cold weather gets you down this movie will put you back in the Christmas spirit and make you appreciate the beauty of cold and icy weather like never before.  Watching this movie you can physically feel the cold, but like the kids in the movie running around in pajamas it allows you to see and feel its beauty in comfort.  The train take you on a magical journey where you meet a nomadic character who lives as a train-hopper and serves as your gaurdian angel, and in the end if you overcome your fears you get to meet the most magical one of all, Santa Claus.  The frost that glistens and shines literally jumps off the screen at you from the frozen train.
My grandchildren and I enjoyed the movie very much. This is a movie for all ages.  Tom Hanks does a excellent job.
This movie holds the attention of young and old alike and has become our Christmas Eve favorite.  Believable with elements of imagination.
Can't beat this movie for the Christmas season. Great animation and the kids always love this story. Anything with Hanks is good

First of all this is a great movie in 2D, but in 3D it really struts its' stuff.  The scenes as the train makes its' way to the North Pole are incredible and may cause vertigo in some viewers.  Outstanding blu-ray.
Really enjoyed The Polar Express film. Captivating and uplifting. Great movie for the whole family. Would recommend this movie especially for train lovers.
wonderful movie and the price was great, it is actually a fun to watch movie. Recommend to any family with small kids.
Too scary and a little creepy.too much peril for little ones.the train is not a fun place to be.menacing plot and weird kid in the back of the train is creepy

This movie is a very good movie,A  Train Ride To The North Pole To See Santa Claus, there are very happy kids.

Hi,

This movie was great. However, as a person of color, I wish that they had not shown Santa's face. It would have provided a lot more opportunity for children to imagine Santa in whatever color or image that they wanted.  If that had happened, I would have rated the movie 5 stars.  Hopefully in the future, there will be a movie that provides a more imaginative view of Santa.

I watched this in the theatre when it came out and was so bored, I couldn't wait for it to end.  Now all these years later,  I have kids, and I thought I'd give it another chance.  My oldest son thinks the movie is okay, but my younger (6 years old) was rolling all around bored stiff.

My second assessment is that the characters are not charming and some are down right creepy.  The train ride to get to the North Pole is dark and boring.  There is little visually appealing.  They could have done so much with this film and did not.  I never understood all the great reviews.  I don't think there's really a strong message either.

I don't think this is a classic in any sense and won't be watching it again.
I guess they are trying to take a short book and make it into a movie and it was just very long and drawn out. The 3D was barely noticeable.

I used the full screen edition to show my k - 4 children.  First I set up two rows of chairs in front of the projector screen. The children boarded the train after getting their tickets punched by the conductor. They loved it!!

Great Movie, but then again, if you have kids and haven't seen it yet you probably don't own a TV.

I am a longtime fan of "The Polar Express" and I have loved the book since I was a child. Ever since I was a child, I've always had dreams of the book turning into a movie. Many years later, "The Polar Express" turned into a movie and my dream came true. I hope yours did when you read the book or when your parents read it to you when you were a child. This movie will get YOU and YOUR family in the Christmas Spirit after you watch this wonderful Christmas movie on rails.
Loved the movie, effects, and Tom Hanks.  It really captures the true meaning of Christmas.  Recommend it to all.  Thanks, Robert.
I simply love this movie.  The picture quality is very nice, and my kiddos love it!  Very satisfied with this purchase!

This movie is pure magic.  It appeals to young and old alike.  One of our favorite Christmas books is Polar Express, magic also, but to see it come alive right in your living room....you can reach out and touch it, feel it in your whole body! The 3-D is amazing, your right there in the movie experience.  I found myself reaching out trying to catch the train ticket that got away.  And it snowed in my living room! And Tom Hanks.....that man is pure magic himself!  You simply believe.....the message comes across crystal clear.  And that's what the season is all about .  Magic, love and fellowship and good will to man.  Keep the magic and faith in your heart, not just Christmas, but everyday.

Polar Express is among a handful of true Christmas classics which my grandson and I can enjoy together.  In addition to an exciting story, it deals with ideas and ideals which we can then discuss.  We will enjoy this holiday adventure for many, many years to come.
There is nothing better than this movie at Christmas time.  Saint Nicholas and the Bells should ring for all to hear.

I play this movie every year for my Kindergarten students.

Lots of fun for everyone!

This particular version with the kid standing in front of the train is absolutely lousy in 3D.The picture has red lines silhouetting everything in the picture. If it offers red and blue 3D glasses with the movie,avoid it at all cost. You will hate it as I and everyone else who tried this one did.
On the other hand,the version with the train going over the bridge,with the kid standing on top of the train on the cover,worked fine,so,be careful which one you order. I give that one five stars! so,if you order one,be sure to order this one,not the other one.

Warner did a great job on the 3D pictures

I love this movie and thought that I would get the 3D version.  I purchased it early in the year, but didn't watch it until Christmastime.  The 3-D didn't work.  There was a red and green shadow when we attempted to watch it on our LG 3-D television with the LG 3-D glasses.  We even tried to use the 3-D glasses that came with the movie, but no success.  I'll have to investigate why this happened since no other 3-D movie we have purchased has given us this problem.  So be warned.  Check if there is a particular type of 3-D viewing required.

Of all the Christmas stories to have come out in the past twenty five or so years this is the only one with the magic I require to be in a good Yule story. Many contemporary writers of children's story's resort to cuteness and cheap emotive melodrama to make their stories interesting. Not so with the author of The Polar Express. The plot is one that does not stretch my imagination to the breaking point for believability. I think this is one of the best screen adaptations of a children's book to come along in many a year. This is the reason I bought the book and the movie for my 5 year old grandson.
